{"step_by_step_thinking": "Insulin, glucagon, and calcitonin are peptide hormones. They are water-soluble and cannot cross the cell membrane. They bind to receptors on the cell surface and trigger a cascade of reactions inside the cell. On the other hand, thyroxine is a thyroid hormone, which is lipid-soluble. Lipid-soluble hormones can cross the cell membrane and act on receptors inside the cell.", "answer_choice": "A"}
